utterances: And when you say it's hard to track down the parents, why?
I mean, what are the obstacles for you?
So finding the parent's name, trying to find their contact information - if the parent was already deported, we need to find their phone number in their home country.
That can be rural areas.
So the communication is very difficult at times.
Sometimes we cannot find where the parent is detained, and that takes a little bit of time as well.
It's just a very complicated process.
Was that boy - that 7-year-old boy reunited with his family?
He is in the process of reuniting right now.
We were able finally to communicate with his family.
This work must take a toll on you and your team as well.
That is correct.
Working with very young children is heartbreaking.
It takes an emotional toll on me as an attorney and all of our staff.
But we have to do it.
We know that these children need someone by their side.
They need someone to help them throughout this complicated immigration system.
And our focus is really to help the children.
Pamela Florian - she's an attorney with the nonprofit Florence Immigrant and Refugee Rights Project.
Thanks very much for your time.
Thank you for having me.
Families have passed down Christmas cookie recipes for generations, but few traditions date back further than this one from Medieval Europe.
Marie Cusick reports for NPR from Strasburg, Pennsylvania.
At Heather Botchlet's bakery in the heart of Pennsylvania Dutch Country, it's not uncommon for an Amish horse and buggy to pass by.
(SOUNDBITE OF A HORSE AND BUGGY)
But even though many of her neighbors are still living as if it's the 19th century, the tradition Botchlet is keeping alive is much older.
She's one of a handful of commercial bakers in the country making Springerle cookies, which date back to medieval Germany.
The small white cookies are more than holiday treats; they are literally edible pieces of art history.
In Germany, they'd be called Springerle, and they were made in the Southern German region, and not just at Christmastime, they were made all year round.
The oldest-known Springerle mold, which now sits in the Swiss National Museum in Zurich, dates back to the 14th century.
Botchlet makes the cookies by pressing dough into the molds.
After an overnight wait and time in the oven, they reveal intricate relief images of everything from flowers, to animals, and scenes from the Bible and everyday life centuries ago.
Everybody's going to grab a blanket, sit on the floor, hug each other, dogs included, and thank God for what we are blessed with.
On this issue, I think we have to really have the cooperation of China because China has a very big role in dealing with North Korea.
So, I think Japan, United States are okay, will continue to be talking this issue with China.
Ichiro Fujisaki is Japan's ambassador to the United States.
Thank so much for coming in.
It's nice to see you again.
Thank you very much, Liane-san.
It was so nice to talk to you.
This is DAY TO DAY, I'm Alex Chadwick.
After East Timor gained its independence from Indonesia, the island nation hoped to get rich from offshore oil reserves.
But Australia, much bigger, much more powerful, already rich, and a neighbor, also claimed rights in the area.
Now the two have reached an agreement that could soon bring billions of dollars to both.
NPR's Michael Sullivan reports.
Australia has been a good friend to East Timor in many ways.
Australian troops led the international peacekeeping force sent to quell the violence after the Timorese voted for independence.
Australia is also one of East Timor's biggest foreign donors.
But the dispute over the rich gas and oil deposits in the Timor Sea has been long and acrimonious.
The two sides have now agreed to share the revenue 50/50, though Australia's Prime Minister, John Howard, suggested the real winners were the Timorese.
It provides, over the years ahead, a very important addition to the revenue stream coming to a tiny, independent country.
And there's great affection in Australia for East Timor.
There's great sympathy for the people of East Timor.
There's a great desire on the part of the people of Australia that the people of East Timor have a strong, secure future.
Great affection and great sympathy, perhaps, but not great enough, critics say, to give the Timorese what they were entitled to.
The biggest and potentially most lucrative field in the disputed area lies much closer to East Timor than Australia.
And many familiar with maritime law say East Timor had a good case for claiming all the disputed territory under international law.
But Australia refused to participate in an international arbitration process.
It claimed an agreement it had signed with Indonesia in the 1970s remains valid.
That agreement gave Australia the rights to most of the disputed area.
East Timor's one of the poorest countries in East Asia.
Nearly half the population lives on less than 50 cents a day.
One-in-ten children fails to reach the age of five.
In the end, some analysts say, the Timorese government evidently decided that a bad deal was better than no deal at all.
It will mean that we have the means, the financial means to increase our budget expenditure for education, for public health, for our infrastructure development to serve the rural areas.
East Timor's Foreign Minister Jose Ramos-Horta.

It will mean, also, that we can create infrastructures that are necessary, like bridges, ports, expand our airport, open roads, and all of these will create thousands of jobs, and in the end will contribute towards poverty alleviation and poverty elimination in our country.
Both countries must still ratify the agreement before it takes effect and before development begins.
Both are expected later this year.
Michael Sullivan, NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
For the next couple of weeks, we're going to be doing some stories about some of the volunteers who've gone to help in the aftermath of Katrina.
We're beginning today with Ron Weckbacher.
He's a member of a national organization that trains dogs and sends them to search for and help recover victims and to locate bodies in times of disaster.
More from reporter Gloria Hillard.
In a welcome-home crowd waving homemade signs, flowers and small American flags, volunteer rescue worker Ron Weckbacher holds the leashes of Manny and Dawson.
They are two almost look-alike white-and-black border collies, and the dogs have just been spotted by a small crowd of smiling children.
Hi, Isabella.
Did you see Dawson?
He likes little kids.
Be careful, though.
He's going to give you a big old smooch right in your face.
Ron Weckbacher is a 44-year-old financial adviser for Morgan Stanley, but on this day, he's wearing LA Fire Department-issued blue baseball cap, T-shirt, pants and heavy work boots.
Weckbacher is a volunteer with the National Disaster Search Dog Foundation.
In this role, he accompanied the LA Fire Department's task force to the Gulf Coast.
You can offer them a lot of hope and a lot of help, but just sad to see all that they had to go through.
He looks a little weary.
One free hand is always resting on one of his dogs.
Manny, still in his orange vest, is trained to find live bodies.
Dawson, who has pale green eyes, has a tougher job; he's trained to find those who can no longer be helped.
He did so well.
You would have been so proud of him.
He kept searching and searching and searching.
He did not stop.
He got some cuts, got some punctures; it never fazed him.
A majority of FEMA-certified canine rescue teams in the hurricane-affected areas were trained by the National Disaster Search Dog Foundation.
The non-profit organization relies on donations and dedicated volunteers who are partnered for this rescue work with dogs that have been rescued themselves from shelters and rescue organizations.
For Weckbacher, it's been two weeks since he left home.
There's my boy!
Give me a hug.
Oh, I missed you so much.
I know.
You tell him, Dawson.
While away, he's been sleeping on the ground, sorrowful ground.
So the question he's heard many times before...
Why do this?
You know, it's real simple.
Everybody gives in their own way.
This is just the way that I give.

Weckbacher, who has responded to a number of disasters--from 9/11 to mudslides to the flattened dreams of Biloxi, Mississippi--says they all have one thing in common, something that affects both victims and rescue workers: grief.
Easing that grief is another part of the dogs' job.
They are my comfort, and I cannot tell you how many times people come up to me and say, `Can I pet your dog?
and they just love having that creature to be able to hold and to pet.
It's very, very therapeutic for a lot of people.
Still, even if Barney Frank's bill passed, it wouldn't force lenders to participate, so it might not help as many people as advertised.
Another bill out there, though, would empower bankruptcy judges to order lenders to help borrowers and change their loan terms.
There's still a lot of opposition to that.
Mike Calhoun is the president of Center for Responsible Lending.
He says under other proposals, the Federal Government would loan or grant billions of dollars to cities so they could buy up foreclosed properties.
Then resell them to non-profit organizations such as Habitat for Humanity, who in turn picks up the houses and sell them to new homeowners.
Not all these bills will pass; there are still lots of economists and lawmakers who are opposed to putting taxpayer dollars on the line.
But until the mess in the housing and credit markets gets better, we're likely to see increasing pressure to do just that.
Chris Arnold, NPR News.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
